Eightieth session 
Sixth Committee 
 
 
 
Organization of work 
 
 
Note by the Secretariat 
 
 
1. 
In order to assist the Sixth Committee in the organization of its work, the 
Secretariat considers it appropriate, in the light of General Assembly resolutions 1898 
(XVIII) of 11 November 1963 and 32/71 of 9 December 1977 and of rule 99 (b) of 
the rules of procedure of the Assembly, to draw the attention of the Committee to the 
information below. 
 
Items allocated to the Sixth Committee 
 
2. 
At its 2nd plenary meeting, held on 12 September 2025, the General Assembly 
allocated 34 items to the Sixth Committee. The list of those items, organized under 
headings corresponding to the priorities of the Organization, is contained in a note by 
the Secretariat on the allocation of agenda items to the Committee, which has been 
circulated as a document of the Committee (A/C.6/80/1). The Committee’s attention 
is drawn to the relevant parts of sections III and IV of the report of the General 
Committee (A/80/250) concerning the agenda of the Main Committees and to the 
recommendations on the organization of the session contained in section II of the 
same report. Those recommendations were approved by the Assembly at its 
2nd plenary meeting. 
 
Documentation relating to the items allocated to the Sixth Committee 
 
3. 
The table below lists the documents of the eightieth session of the General 
Assembly relating to the items allocated to the Sixth Committee. It includes 
references to the reports of commissions or committees and the reports that are to be 
submitted by the Secretary-General pursuant to resolutions or decisions of the 
Assembly at preceding sessions, as well as to documents circulated under the agenda 
items allocated to the Committee,1 in accordance with requests of Member States. The 
attention of delegates is also drawn to the website of the Committee. 2

Programme of work 
 
4. 
Rule 99 (b) of the rules of procedure of the General Assembly provides that: 
Each Main Committee, taking into account the closing date for the session fixed 
by the General Assembly on the recommendation of the General Committee, 
shall adopt its own priorities and meet as may be necessary to complete the 
consideration of the items referred to it. It shall at the beginning of the session 
adopt a programme of work indicating, if possible, a target date for the 

A/C.6/80/L.1 
 
25-14774
6/10 
 
conclusion of its work, the approximate dates of consideration of items and the 
number of meetings to be allocated to each item. 
5. 
Pursuant to General Assembly resolution 77/335 on further measures for the 
revitalization of the work of the Assembly, upon the recommendation of the Sixth 
Committee, the Assembly, at its 47th plenary meeting, held on 4 December 2024, 
adopted decision 79/524 containing the provisional programme of work of the 
Committee for the eightieth session of the Assembly. 
6. 
The General Assembly, at its 2nd plenary meeting, held on 12 September 2025, 
upon the recommendation of the General Committee (see A/80/250), fixed the target 
date of 21 November 2025 for the completion of the work of the Sixth Committee. 
7. 
The Bureau of the Committee has considered the provisional programme of 
work as contained in decision 79/524 and has taken into account the allocation of 
additional items (requests for observer status in the General Assembly) to the 
Committee by the General Assembly, as well as the reduction of the length of the 
report of the International Law Commission on the work of its seventy-sixth session 
(as a consequence of the reduction of the length of the Commission’s session) and the 
anticipated workload at the present session. The programme has been prepared 
accordingly.

Establishment of working groups and holding of consultations 
 
8. 
Concerning agenda item 76, entitled “Responsibility of States for 
internationally wrongful acts”, the General Assembly, by its resolution 77/97, decided 
to include the item in the provisional agenda of its eightieth session and to further 
examine, within the framework of a working group of the Sixth Committee and with 
a view to taking a decision, the question of a convention on responsibility of States 
for internationally wrongful acts or other appropriate action on the basis of the articles 
on responsibility of States for internationally wrongful acts. In the light of that, three 
meetings, to be held on 15 October and 3 and 7 November, have been suggested for 
that purpose. 
9. 
Concerning agenda item 109, entitled “Measures to eliminate international 
terrorism”, the General Assembly, by its resolution 79/129, decided to recommend 
that the Sixth Committee, at the eightieth session of the Assembly, establish a working 
group with a view to finalizing the process on the draft comprehensive convention on 
international terrorism as well as discussions on the item included in its agenda by 
Assembly resolution 54/110 concerning the question of convening a high-level 
conference under the auspices of the United Nations. In the light of that, two 
meetings, to be held on 17 October and 6 November, have been suggested for that 
purpose. 
10. The consideration of the reports of the working groups in plenary is scheduled 
for 14 November. It has also been suggested that the following be held: a briefing on 
agenda item 77, entitled “Criminal accountability of United Nations officials and 
experts on mission”, on 16 October; and an informal briefing on agenda item 146, 
entitled “Administration of justice at the United Nations”, on 17 October. 
11. In view of the limited conference services available to the Sixth Committee (see 
para. 22), any meetings for the working groups or for informal consultations are 
accommodated within the overall meetings allocated to the Committee. 
12. Concerning agenda item 86, entitled “Protection of persons in the event of 
disasters”, the General Assembly, by its resolution 79/128, decided that the Sixth 
Committee shall resume its session for up to five days by the end of April 2026 at the 
latest, in order to prepare a consolidated text that will serve as the basis for the 
negotiations of a legally binding instrument on the protection of persons in the event 
of disasters, including the draft articles on the protection of persons in the event of 
disasters and the proposals submitted by Governments, within the framework of a 
working group of the Committee. It is expected that the Sixth Committee will include, 
in the forthcoming draft resolution to be prepared under the agenda item, an indication 
of the dates and number of meetings of the working group. 
 
Statements by delegations 
 
13. The list of speakers for the debate on all agenda items opened on 15 September 
2025. Delegations are invited to inscribe their names on the list of speakers through 
the eSpeakers module for the Sixth Committee in the e-deleGATE portal, preferably 

A/C.6/80/L.1
 
9/10
25-14774 
 
by 5 p.m. on the Friday preceding the week in which each agenda item is scheduled 
to be considered (unless otherwise indicated). The live list of speakers for each agenda 
item can be accessed through the e-deleGATE portal, or from the website of the Sixth 
Committee.3 
14. Pursuant to General Assembly resolution 72/313, delegations are encouraged to 
adhere to the “all protocol observed” principle and to refrain from listing standard 
protocol expressions during their statements. In the same resolution, the Assembly 
recommended that speakers should be mindful of the speed of statement delivery, 
bearing in mind the need for accuracy of interpretation. The delivery of national 
statements will be limited to 7 minutes, and group statements to 12 minutes, for all 
agenda items except those dealing with the annual report of the International Law 
Commission, for which delegations are encouraged to limit their statements to main 
positions and views for a total of 12 minutes (with further information or clarifications 
provided in written versions made available through the eStatements portal or in 
written submissions to the Commission). 
15. In accordance with General Assembly decision 34/401, delegations should 
exercise their right of reply at the end of the day whenever two meetings have been 
scheduled for the consideration of the relevant agenda item on that day, or at the 
conclusion of the consideration of the item, if that is sooner. The first statement should 
be limited to five minutes and the second, if any, to three minutes. 
 
Draft resolutions 
 
16. The initiation and sponsorship of draft resolutions, where applicable, will be 
undertaken electronically through the eSponsorship module for the Sixth Committee 
in the e-deleGATE portal. 
17. Unless otherwise agreed, coordinators or main sponsors, as applicable, of 
proposals for draft resolutions are encouraged to hold at least one informal 
consultation per proposal. The Secretariat will provide assistance where necessary. 
Informal consultations should be announced sufficiently in advance, including in the 
Journal of the United Nations, so as to allow participation by representatives of all 
Member States. Once consultations have concluded, it is the practice of the Sixth 
Committee to place proposals for draft resolutions under a silence procedure, prior to 
their submission for processing and issuance in all official languages as limited (“L”) 
documents. 
18. All delegations wishing to sponsor a proposal for a draft resolution, where 
applicable, are encouraged to do so electronically through the eSponsorship module, 
rather than during the formal proceedings of the Committee. This is without prejudice 
to the possibility of delegations sponsoring a proposal for a draft resolution at the 
time of the Committee’s action on the latter during a plenary meeting. Sponsorship 
should take place at the level of the Sixth Committee, given that, once the Committee 
has adopted a proposal for a draft resolution and recommended its adoption by the 
General Assembly, its sponsorship can no longer be altered by Member States. 
Proposals for draft resolutions submitted on behalf of the Bureau are not subject to 
sponsorship. 
19. Pursuant to rule 153 of the rules of procedure of the General Assembly, “no 
resolution involving expenditure shall be recommended by a committee for approval 
by the General Assembly unless it is accompanied by an estimate of expenditures 
prepared by the Secretary-General”. It is therefore imperative that the Sixth 
Committee allow sufficient time for the preparation of estimates of expenditure by 
__________________ 
 
3 See www.un.org/en/ga/sixth/80/programme.shtml. 

A/C.6/80/L.1 
 
25-14774
10/10 
 
the Secretariat and for their consideration by the Advisory Committee on 
Administrative and Budgetary Questions and the Fifth Committee. Bearing in mind 
that 21 November has been fixed as the concluding date for the work of the Sixth 
Committee (see para. 6), 7 November would have to be considered the mandatory 
deadline for submission to the Fifth Committee of draft resolutions with financial 
implications, except for draft resolutions concerning items to be considered after that 
date. When submitting such proposals, delegations may also wish to bear in mind 
that, in most cases, a period of more than 48 hours, up to four days, is required for 
the Secretary-General to review the programme budget implications of proposals. 
Accordingly, the deadline for finalization and submission of all draft resolutions for 
budget review and processing is 14 November 2025. 
20. Each coordinator or main sponsor, as applicable, of proposals for draft 
resolutions will be invited to introduce their respective draft resolutions as issued in 
limited distribution (“L”) documents. Such introductions take place at plenary 
meetings, and will be announced in advance, including in the Journal. 
21. Except for draft resolutions introduced at the final meeting of the substantive 
part of the session on 21 November 2025, it is the practice of the Committee to take 
action on each draft resolution at the plenary meeting following that at which the draft 
resolution was introduced, or at a later date. Any anticipated action on draft 
resolutions or decisions will be announced in advance, including in the Journal and 
on the website of the Committee. It is the practice of the Sixth Committee to strive 
for the adoption of draft resolutions without taking a vote. 
 
Conference resources available 
 
22. The available conference facilities will, in principle, enable the Committee to 
hold between three and six plenary meetings per week. Morning meetings will be held 
from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. and afternoon meetings from 3 to 6 p.m. 
23. Unless otherwise specified, formal meetings of the Committee will be held from 
10 a.m. to 1 p.m. and from 3 to 6 p.m. in the Trusteeship Council Chamber. The General 
Assembly has stressed that a punctual start to the meetings is critical to the efficient 
utilization of services allocated to the intergovernmental bodies of the United Nations. 
In accordance with past practice, rule 108 of the rules of procedure of the Assembly 
could be waived with respect to the quorum needed to declare a meeting open.

In the same resolution, the Assembly recommended that speakers should be mindful of the speed of statement delivery, bearing in mind the need for accuracy of interpretation. The delivery of national statements will be limited to 7 minutes, and group statements to 12 minutes, for all agenda items except those dealing with the annual report of the International Law Commission, for which delegations are encouraged to limit their statements to main positions and views for a total of 12 minutes (with further information or clarifications provided in written versions made available through the eStatements portal or in written submissions to the Commission).
paragraphs.15: In accordance with General Assembly decision 34/401, delegations should exercise their right of reply at the end of the day whenever two meetings have been scheduled for the consideration of the relevant agenda item on that day, or at the conclusion of the consideration of the item, if that is sooner. The first statement should be limited to five minutes and the second, if any, to three minutes. Draft resolutions
paragraphs.16: The initiation and sponsorship of draft resolutions, where applicable, will be undertaken electronically through the eSponsorship module for the Sixth Committee in the e-deleGATE portal.
paragraphs.17: Unless otherwise agreed, coordinators or main sponsors, as applicable, of proposals for draft resolutions are encouraged to hold at least one informal consultation per proposal. The Secretariat will provide assistance where necessary. Informal consultations should be announced sufficiently in advance, including in the Journal of the United Nations, so as to allow participation by representatives of all Member States. Once consultations have concluded, it is the practice of the Sixth Committee to place proposals for draft resolutions under a silence procedure, prior to their submission for processing and issuance in all official languages as limited (“L”) documents.
paragraphs.18: All delegations wishing to sponsor a proposal for a draft resolution, where applicable, are encouraged to do so electronically through the eSponsorship module, rather than during the formal proceedings of the Committee. This is without prejudice to the possibility of delegations sponsoring a proposal for a draft resolution at the time of the Committee’s action on the latter during a plenary meeting. Sponsorship should take place at the level of the Sixth Committee, given that, once the Committee has adopted a proposal for a draft resolution and recommended its adoption by the General Assembly, its sponsorship can no longer be altered by Member States. Proposals for draft resolutions submitted on behalf of the Bureau are not subject to sponsorship.
paragraphs.19: Pursuant to rule 153 of the rules of procedure of the General Assembly, “no resolution involving expenditure shall be recommended by a committee for approval by the General Assembly unless it is accompanied by an estimate of expenditures prepared by the Secretary-General”. It is therefore imperative that the Sixth Committee allow sufficient time for the preparation of estimates of expenditure by the Secretariat and for their consideration by the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions and the Fifth Committee. Bearing in mind that 21 November has been fixed as the concluding date for the work of the Sixth Committee (see para. 6), 7 November would have to be considered the mandatory deadline for submission to the Fifth Committee of draft resolutions with financial implications, except for draft resolutions concerning items to be considered after that date. When submitting such proposals, delegations may also wish to bear in mind that, in most cases, a period of more than 48 hours, up to four days, is required for the Secretary-General to review the programme budget implications of proposals. Accordingly, the deadline for finalization and submission of all draft resolutions for budget review and processing is 14 November 2025.
paragraphs.20: Each coordinator or main sponsor, as applicable, of proposals for draft resolutions will be invited to introduce their respective draft resolutions as issued in limited distribution (“L”) documents. Such introductions take place at plenary meetings, and will be announced in advance, including in the Journal.
paragraphs.21: Except for draft resolutions introduced at the final meeting of the substantive part of the session on 21 November 2025, it is the practice of the Committee to take action on each draft resolution at the plenary meeting following that at which the draft resolution was introduced, or at a later date. Any anticipated action on draft resolutions or decisions will be announced in advance, including in the Journal and on the website of the Committee. It is the practice of the Sixth Committee to strive for the adoption of draft resolutions without taking a vote. Conference resources available
paragraphs.22: The available conference facilities will, in principle, enable the Committee to hold between three and six plenary meetings per week. Morning meetings will be held from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. and afternoon meetings from 3 to 6 p.m.
paragraphs.23: Unless otherwise specified, formal meetings of the Committee will be held from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. and from 3 to 6 p.m. in the Trusteeship Council Chamber. The General Assembly has stressed that a punctual start to the meetings is critical to the efficient utilization of services allocated to the intergovernmental bodies of the United Nations. In accordance with past practice, rule 108 of the rules of procedure of the Assembly could be waived with respect to the quorum needed to declare a meeting open.
